data.text: Contents
Introduction
This document sets out the Policy for managing ventilation and air-conditioning
Systems at Mid and South Essex NHS Foundation Trust (referred hereafter as Trust).

Ventilation is used extensively in all types of healthcare premises to provide a safe and comfortable environment for patients and staff. More specialised ventilation is provided in areas such as operating departments, critical care areas and isolation facilities for primary patient treatment. Refrigeration plant also preserves food so that it can be bought and prepared in bulk at economic costs and then later served for safe consumption. In addition, refrigeration plant is used for preserving drugs and specimens at safe temperatures and for the preservation of bodies in the mortuary until collection can be arranged. Cooling is provided both within clinical areas and pharmacy to maintain ambient medicines within safe and licensed storage conditions
It is also installed:
To ensure compliance with the quality assurance requirements of items processed in pharmacies and sterile services departments;
To protect staff from harmful organisms and toxic substances (for example in laboratories).
Scope
The purpose of this document is to:
Provide staff and contractors with the standards required for the supply, installation and maintenance of all Mechanical Ventilation systems within Trust properties.
Provide a framework for the Trust to manage air handling systems, inclusive of when building and refurbishment works have to be carried out and the air handling system is included in the scheme.

To ensure that all ventilation and air conditioning equipment is installed, inspected, serviced and maintained in accordance with all Statutory Instruments and guidance relevant to the NHS. With particular emphasis placed on meeting best practice guidance sited within.

Obstetrics: (i) maternity theatres; (ii) birthing rooms. Critical areas and high dependency units of any type. Isolation facilities: (i) infectious diseases units; (ii) bone marrow and other transplant units; (iii) chemotherapy and oncology units. Sterile services departments: (i) wash rooms; (ii) inspection and packing rooms; (iii) storage rooms. Pharmacy departments: (i) aseptic suites; (ii) extemporaneous preparation areas; (iii) radio pharmacies Pathology departments: (i) laboratories; (ii) Category 3 and 4 rooms. Mortuary and post-mortem rooms: (i) mortuaries; (ii) post-mortem rooms; (iii) specimen stores. Hydrotherapy units.

Burns units: (i) burns theatres; (ii) treatment rooms; (iii) isolation rooms; (iv) tissue banks. Emerging specialties: (i) gene therapy units; (ii) stem-cell laboratories. Infrastructure: (i) plantrooms housing combustion equipment; (ii) welding facilities; (iii) woodworking workshops; (iv) electric-vehicle charging areas.

Ventilation and cooling systems
Types of ventilation and cooling systems
Health and comfort is achieved by the following systems:
heating
natural ventilation
mechanical ventilation
mechanical ventilation cooling or air conditioning
comfort cooling air conditioning
full air conditioning

Natural ventilation is defined as the ability to open windows (for guidance on this see Window Safety Policy) for fresh air while mechanical ventilation systems contain fans that use energy to move air through ductwork and have higher capital and running costs that impact on EFM capital and operational budgets.
Mechanical ventilation air conditioning therefore has the highest possible environmental impact and results in the highest energy costs.

There is no legal maximum working temperature in the workplace (that provides advice when ventilation and cooling may be needed) but the law requires employers to ensure the temperature in all workplaces inside buildings shall be reasonable.
Factors
Requests for ventilation and cooling are increasing driven primarily by the following factors:
1) More patients than ever before are using the hospital often accommodated in large public waiting areas
2) Higher expectations by patients, staff and visitors for a comfortable, quality internal environment
3) Increasing heat gains by the use of process or medical and IT equipment
4) Increasing demands for close control of the internal environment by compliance and license regulation bodies
5) Climate change and changing weather patterns are causing global temperatures in general to increase
6) Increased site activity and development causes less heat release and natural night time cooling of buildings often called the heat island effect
7) Compliance to HTM  Windows that limits the opening of windows to 100 mm to prevent a determined effort to force open a window
Recommended hospital temperatures
There is no definition of what is "reasonable" room temperature, but the CIBSE guidancerecommends the following summer time temperatures for hospitals.

Recommended Office Temperatures

CIBSE also recommends for offices 25oC as an acceptable summer time temperature and a limit benchmark of oC for no more than 1% of the annual occupied times. (This will need to be measured by EFM staff as part of the assessment process)
Recommended medication storage temperatures
Medication storage temperatures warrant special attention. Many medication license holders mandate that their product must be stored below  oC. Storage

continuously above this temperature for Defined Periods may cause therapeutic failure through denaturing of the drug. Shelf-life is therefore also affected. Each Medicines storage is determined on a case by case basis according to licensing, evidence and pharmacy recommendations.

The ward or department monitors local temperatures daily or these are monitored remotely by EFM (Southend Site locations. If temperatures persistently go above 25 oC then the ward or department or pharmacy will ask facilities (via the EFM help desk) to investigate and put in place appropriate remedial measures. Please refer to MSEPO-20205 Policy for Safe and Secure Storage of Medicines for further details.
Heat gains
Heat is generated in buildings from the following sources:
People – occupancy gains
A typical person emits about 100 Watts of heat. Occupancy densities in the hospital generally are as follows:
1 person for every 4 mfloor space
This means that occupancy heat gains are typically  W/m.
Lighting

Office lighting typically gives a heat gain of 10 Watts/m illuminated to about 350- 400 lux and includes power used by the control gear. Energy efficient lighting and controls will reduce heat gains into the occupied area.
Heat producing equipment
These may be significant and cause high heat gains in the occupied area due to high lighting levels, multi-functional devices, printers, photocopiers, fax machines, fridge freezers, scanners, etc.

Such gains should ideally be located outside the occupied area. If this is not possible then some form of cooling may be required especially in a laboratory area, for instance, where natural ventilation may not be adequate. Actual heat gains are often overstated as the electrical load of some types of equipment is usually well below that stated on the nameplate.
Heat gains from IT equipment in an office area can be assumed to be no more than 15 W/m2.
Solar gains
Solar gains are often the highest heat gain into an occupied area and vary from day to day and throughout the year. The following factors also affect solar gains:
window orientation - maximum gain through south and west facing windows
window area - as a percentage of the total wall area
type of glazing
shading and its location

Removal of heat gains
Estimated or predicted heat gains may be removed and thermal comfort achieved by the use of the following systems.
Natural ventilation  40-50 W/m2
Mechanical ventilation   50-60 W/m2
Mechanical ventilation cooling  60-70 W/m2

A survey or risk assessment of the occupied area may need to be carried out (initially by the local manager experiencing the over-heating issue and then in- house maintenance staff) to evaluate the optimum solution with due consideration to site or building constraints and financial constraints.
Fans (including air conditioning units)

Air movement as part of natural ventilation is important and can in certain circumstances be provided by stand-alone fans, bladed fans only; as indeed the use in an emergency or under accentuating circumstances the use of portable air conditioning units.

Requests for such equipment shall be through the Facilities Helpdesk and be subject to audit and appraisal (by Maintenance Operatives) including checks on the electrical distribution to see if sufficient capacity exists.

It should be noted that the cost of these fans will have to be borne by the department or service making the request while the cost of the portable air conditioning units would be subject to negotiation.

The decision to use fans in clinical areas must be on a risk based approach in accordance with guidance from Infection Prevention team. All portable fans used in clinical areas should be clinically risk assessed for each use and reuse. Availability of manufacturers' information and advice on how to maintain and decontaminate the fan. This should be consistent with national and local infection prevention and control policy. Consideration should be given to whether the fan can be adequately decontaminated for safe reuse or whether it should be disposed of after use. Any portable fans determined by risk assessment to present an infection risk should be removed from clinical use.
Fans must be cleaned in accordance with the Cleaning Policy and national cleanliness specification and covered when stored to avoid dust collection.
Ventilation and cooling flow chart procedure (Appendix 1)

Services experiencing the effects of lack of ventilation and/or over-heating due to high heat gains, etc. need to request a “cooling” assessment via the Facilities Helpdesk which will be undertaken by the Head of Sustainability or deputy.

Maintenance staff would in the first instance take temperature readings, check window openings, changes in occupancy usage, etc. and be advised or guided by the local Site Manager and / or the Maintenance Manager. The Health and Safety Manager or deputy would also be able to help and advice (especially if a Datix incident is reported).
Appendix 1 defines a procedure to help evaluate this Policy and determine the various issues.
Heat gain calculation tool
This is an Excel spread sheet based tool which by inputting the variable data defined in 1) to 4) above predicts for a specific occupied area the internal heat gains in Watts per m2.
The tool allows a re-design of the occupied area to reduce heat gains and simulate the likely effects.

If following any redesign the heat gains are still higher than 50-60 W/m2 then some form of energy using mechanical ventilation or cooling may be needed in the occupied area as natural ventilation alone may not achieve an acceptable internal environment. This will, however, be subject to financial and building or site constraints and risk assessment.
SLR recharges
Where additional ventilation and cooling is identified, then the Service or Dept. will be expected to fund its installation including recharging of utility costs as part of the SLR process.
General requirements for managing ventilation / air conditioning
units
General Requirements for Managing Ventilation / Air Conditioning Systems All ventilation systems should be inspected annually to ensure conformity with minimum requirements, which are designed to:
ensure safe access when carrying out routine service and maintenance activities;
prevent or control risks associated with Legionella and other potential hazardous organisms;
check that the system remains fit for purpose.
Every effort should be made to ensure that all AHUs achieve the minimum requirement set out in Section 3 of HTM 03-01 Part B: Operational management and performance verification
Maintenance

All service and maintenance procedures shall conform to the principles set out in HTM 03-01 Part B: Operational management and performance verification, ACOP L8, and supportive “HTM 04-01 guideline, HVCA SFG20 and manufactures recommendations
Information
Maintenance and routine inspections records shall be maintained for ventilation plant, and kept within the Facilities & Estates Department electronic database (CAFM system and MICAD)
For the safety of contractors and maintenance staff the following information shall be provided adjacent to the plant to which it refers:
a) General information regarding the intended operation of the plant together with a schematic diagram of the equipment and its distribution system.

b) Information concerning the purpose of the plant and details of those departments and/or personnel served by the plant and who should be informed prior to switching off or carrying out maintenance activities.
c) Information required for the safety of the personnel carrying out the service and maintenance activities.
These procedures set out a frequency of tests, appropriate recording sheets and guidance. All maintenance will conform to the principles set out in HTM03-01 and HTM04-01
Design and installation
The design and installation of new equipment is fundamental to the long term provision of suitable systems which will perform well over a 15-20 year time frame.
All ventilation/air conditioning equipment shall be appropriate for the area it is being designed for and it is only installed where absolutely necessary.
All ventilation/air conditioning equipment is to be designed and installed by suitably qualified personnel and complies with the requirements of HTM 03-01 and other statutory legislation.

Systems shall be designed to the highest standards in terms of energy usage to ensure that the Trusts carbon and sustainability agenda are not compromised. Cooling and/or air conditioning will only be installed in Trust buildings where there is a specific patient imperative or where critical plant or other material (such a medicinal) needs to be maintained within prescribed temperature parameters. Cooling in office areas is unlikely to meet this criterion.

All installations should be easily accessible for maintenance and testing of all maintainable parts and components without the need for specialist access equipment and/or removal of building fabric and finishes.

When new equipment is accepted for use, full information as to its designed mode of operation together with maintenance procedures is provided as part of the handover procedures and prior to system use and added onto the Asset register

The users and those who maintain the system need to be instructed in its safe operation and how to provide the correct environmental conditions as part of the handover procedure at the end of the commissioning period.

It is desirable for medication storage for temperatures not be manually changed by users that may result in out-of-range storage conditions. Disabling functions on user panels are recommended, along with covers to avoid accidental switch off.
All handover documentation will be retained by the Estates and Facilities Department or those with their delegated authority. Where appropriate, copies will also be held within the User Department.
Maintenance procedures and inspection
Ventilation system plant inspections (quarterly, 6 monthly and annual)
It is recommended that a simple check sheet be used to record the result of the inspection.
Examples are given in Appendices 1 and 2 of HTM  Part B
All ventilation systems, as a minimum, will be subject to: An annual visual inspection to ensure that the system is still required.
For each inspection an electronic or simple check sheet will be utilised.
Record will include chlorination information for chlorination of chiller batteries and humidifiers
Description of ventilation systems and classification
Ventilation systems within the Trust are divided into two categories; critical and noncritical.
The criterion below defines those ventilation systems which are considered critical:
The loss of service from such a system would seriously degrade the ability of the premises to deliver optimal healthcare.

The Authorised person is responsible for ensuring that an inventory of critical and non-critical ventilation systems is kept up to date. This inventory will be discussed and signed off by the Infection Prevention Control Team.
Annual verification for critical ventilation systems

All specialist ventilation systems will be subject to an annual verification to ensure: The ventilation system should achieve not less than 75% of the design air-change rate, or its original design parameters. Old design parameters based on plant age can be obtained from HTM 03-01, Microbiological Commissioning and Monitoring of Operating Theatre Suites (Lidwell. 1972), IHVE Guide (1965 edition).

The pressure regime should achieve not less than 75% of the design value given in Appendix 2 of Part A HTM03-01, or its original design parameters, and the pressure gradient relationships with regards to surrounding areas must be maintained. Old design parameters based on plant age can be obtained from HTM 03-01,Microbiological Commissioning and Monitoring of Operating Theatre Suites (Lidwell. 1972),IHVE Guide (1965 edition).

The sound levels quoted in HTM 03-01 Part B Table 2 (page 12) are maximum permissible levels and should not be exceeded. Measurements should be made using at least a Type 2 sound meter fitted with a muff. Its accuracy should be checked using a calibration sound source before use.
Further guidance from HTM03-01 Part B paragraphs 4.19 to 4.28 are followed as appropriate for specialist areas.

Sterile services department – inspection and packing rooms should conform to the requirements of BS EN ISO 14644 and any additional requirements for the processing of medical devices, if applicable (see also Health Building Note 13 – ‘Sterile services department').
Filter changing

The routine changing of filters should be carried out either when the manometer across the filters reaches the designed change limit or on a time basis, provided the designed manometer maximum pressure differential is not exceeded. Suitable records of filter changes will be kept in line with HTM03-01 Part B
AHU drainage
AHU drainage systems comprise a drainage tray, glass trap, connecting pipework and an air break.

The system should be inspected to ensure that it is clean and operating correctly. The cleanliness of the drainage tray and colour of the water in the trap will give an indication of a fault condition (see Table below).

data.text: Chilled beams
The efficiency of these units will rapidly decline if they become blocked with fluff/lint.
They should be inspected every six months and cleaned as appropriate.
Split and cassette air-conditioning units

These units incorporate internal recirculation air filters and a drainage system to remove condensate from the cooling coil. The systems should be inspected and cleaned every three months. These systems are also subject to the F-Gas regulations and as such are to be inspected as part of the maintenance regime to Cibse TM44 guidance.
Ventilation system cleaning
The efficiency of these units will rapidly decline if they become blocked with
fluff/lint.
They should be inspected every six months and cleaned as appropriate.
Air handling units should be cleaned in accordance with HVCA HR/19 guide to good practice for internal cleanliness of ventilation systems

Air Handling Units should be vacuumed-out and/or washed down internally as necessary to remove obvious dust and dirt. Chiller batteries, energy-recovery batteries or plates and their drainage systems should be washed down with hot water annually to remove visible contamination.

Supply air distribution ductwork conveys air that has been filtered. It will require internal cleaning only when it becomes contaminated with visible dirt. The frequency of cleaning will depend on the age of the system and grade of the AHU final filter but will typically be in excess of ten years.
Ventilation supply and extract grill cleaning

The ventilation supply and extract grills are to be cleaned regularly to ensure that dust does not build up. The periodicity of this will be the same as High level dusting as detailed in the National Cleaning Standards for the NHS. This is a routine part of the Domestic Services function; details of these standards are contained in Domestic Standard Operating Procedures.
The intake section of a ventilation system should be vacuumed-out as necessary to remove visible particles.
AHUs should be vacuumed-out and/or washed down internally as necessary to remove obvious dust and dirt.
Chiller batteries, humidifier units, energy-recovery batteries or plates and their drainage systems should be washed down with hot water annually to remove visible contamination.

Supply air distribution ductwork conveys air that has been filtered. It will require internal cleaning only when it becomes contaminated with visible dirt. The frequency of cleaning will depend on the age of the system and grade of the AHU final filter be in excess of ten years. A rapid build-up of visible dirt within a supply duct is an indication of a failure of the filtration or its housing.
The EFM Department will ensure cleaned annually that each supply and extract grill, within patient critical care areas, are disassembled and deep cleaned.
Quarterly chlorination of chilled water circuits

Chilled water refrigeration units must be inspected, cleaned every 3 months. Details of this process are contained within the Legionella procedures; this work may be contracted out, any works that are contracted out will be under a detailed specification under the Trusts contracting arrangement, as a minimum, the contractor must provide the following information:
Portable air-conditioning units

Are available via the EFM Directorate or hired-in when required during excessive building temperatures. They typically incorporate internal recirculation air filters and a drainage system to remove condensate from the cooling coil. The Infection Prevention Control Team must be consulted before these types of units are deployed.

All portable units will be inspected and cleaned weekly while they remain in use. Records of this service and inspection will be kept. The units must be inspected and thoroughly cleaned before being placed into use. Units that are to be used in areas containing immune-compromised patients will, unless new, need to have a bacterial fumigation before being deployed. Units that have been used in isolation rooms or areas containing symptomatic patients MUST be fumigated prior to being utilised in other locations or returned to hirer in line with infection control policies.

Air conditioning units employing an internal water reservoir and wick to promote evaporative cooling will not be used within the Trust; any of these units found in circulation will be immediately removed and destroyed or returned to the hire company if on hire.
Frost protection

Trust ventilation systems will have frost protection in the event of very low outside air temperatures or plant faults. The protection works by detecting the air temperature after the frost/fog coil; should the air temperature be equal to or below 3 C, the plant will stop and the frost/fog coil will open fully. The plant will then not start again until manually reset;
This reset will only happen once it is operationally safe to re-start the plant and no risk of coil failure exists.
Fire dampers

All fire dampers should be tested as part of the annual verification. Fire dampers are fitted in the ventilation system where ducts pass through fire walls and barriers. There are two general types of dampers:
Fusible link spring loaded dampers fitted to older buildings, which require heat from a fire to activate and will not stop smoke penetration prior to the fusible link activating the damper.

Motor driven spring loaded fire dampers activated by the fire alarm system fitted to new buildings and are designed to stop smoke on fire alarm activation. These dampers will be subject to periodic servicing and testing and annual inspection if they form part of a critical ventilation system.
Testing
All specialist ventilation systems should be inspected quarterly and verified at least annually.
In some circumstances the verification may need to be carried out more frequently.
The quarterly inspection should be a simple visual check; the annual verification will be a more detailed inspection of the system together with the measurement of its actual performance.
The annual verification is intended to establish that: the system is still required, the AHU conforms to the minimum standard and the fire containment has not been breached.

The verification should also assess whether the general condition of the ventilation system is adequate, the fabric of the area served is satisfactory and the system performance is adequate with respect to the functional requirement.
Annual verification will require:
a full measure of the supply and extract air-flow rates;
the calculation of room air-change rates if applicable;
the measurement of room differential pressures if applicable;
the measurement of room noise levels;
air-quality checks if appropriate;
a check on the control functions.
Unless otherwise specified below, the ventilation system should achieve not less than 75% of the design air-change rate given in Appendix 2 of HTM 03-01 Part A, or its original design parameters.

The pressure regime should achieve not less than 75% of the design value given in Appendix 2 of Part A, of HTM 03-01 or its original design parameters; and the pressure gradient relationships with regards to surrounding areas must be maintained.

Should a critical system be unable to achieve the standard set out above, it should be taken out of service. If Trust needs prevent the system being taken out of service, the senior manager of the user department should be informed in writing that the system performance is suboptimal.
A copy of the notice should be sent to the infection control department.
Local exhaust ventilation (LEV)
LEV systems use extract ventilation to prevent or reduce the level of airborne hazardous substances from being breathed in by people by drawing pollutants away from the process or operation.
Trust LEV systems typically include:
EFM Workshop wood dust extraction system

Other EFM dust / metal fume extraction/removal systems (N.B. Metal / shot blasting LEV systems require examination monthly, non-ferrous metal working equipment requires and examination every 6 months)
Safety Cabinets Class I-II
Fume hoods
Laminar flow cabinets
Drown draft tables
Surgical smoke extraction systems
Scavenger systems (anaesthetic circuits)
To fulfil the COSHH regulations LEV systems should be examined by a competent person every 14 months.
Theatre maintenance programme

A theatre maintenance programme will be produced by the Authorised Person, which will detail the dates of which duct cleaning, validation, deep cleaning and air testing will be carried out. This plan will be shared with the relevant Business Unit Directors or Assistant Business Unit Directors responsible for the theatres. This will ensure the works are programmed in and any disruption to service can be managed.
11.16.1 Deep Cleaning will be carried out by the Trust's Deep Cleaning Team, after all intrusive maintenance; duct cleaning and validation are carried out.
Training requirements
Training will be carried out by competent persons at specialist training centres.
Competent Person training will be required and carried out at specialist training facilities.

Approval and implementation

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved by the H&S Management Group which is the specialist group with the authority to approve local policies and procedure guidelines. These will then be forwarded to the Document control team for submission and ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.
It is the author's responsibility to inform the H&S Management Group of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.
Equality impact assessment
The Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals.
